user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtMem2HexFile:
```c
bool UtMem2HexFile(const void *Memory, const char *Filename, uint32 Length)
{
    FILE * fp;
    uint32 i;
    uint32 j;

    if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "w")))
    {
        for (i = 0; i < Length; i += 16)
        {
            fprintf(fp, "   %06lX: ", (unsigned long)i);
            for (j = 0; j < 16; j++)
            {
                if ((i + j) < Length)
                    fprintf(fp, "%02X ", ((uint8 *)Memory)[i + j]);
                else
                    fprintf(fp, "   ");
            }
            fprintf(fp, " ");
            for (j = 0; j < 16; j++)
            {
                if ((i + j) < Length)
                    fprintf(fp, "%c", isprint(((uint8 *)Memory)[i + j]) ? ((uint8 *)Memory)[i + j] : '.');
            }
            fprintf(fp, "\n");
        }
        fclose(fp);
        return true;
    }
    else
    {
        printf("UtMem2HexFile: Error Opening File: %s, %s\n", Filename, strerror(errno));
        UtAssert_True(false, "UtMem2HexFile: Error Opening File");
        return false;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtMem2HexFile:
#define UtAssert_True(Expression, __VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(Expression,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
UtAssert_CaseType_t UtAssert_GetContext(void)
{
    return DefaultContext;
}
...
typedef uint8_t   uint8
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only code in this function that is potentially unreachable is the final return false; (and, by dependence, the UtAssert_True call that precedes it) because UtAssert_True expands to a test/assert function (UtAssertEx) whose implementation may not return (e.g. it might terminate the program or longjmp). If UtAssertEx is non-returning, the subsequent return false; is unreachable. To determine whether Rule 2.1 is violated, the implementation/attributes of UtAssertEx (and any noreturn annotations) must be inspected. All other statements in the function are reachable for some valid inputs: the fopen() success and failure branches are both possible at runtime; the outer and inner loops execute when Length>0 and the inner else (fprintf(fp, "   ")) executes when the final line is partial (Length not a multiple of 16); the character-printing if is conditional but reachable for indices < Length. Therefore no other code fragments appear to be statically unreachable.
